awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Doping and Defects in Diamond for Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
Diamond's electronic properties are superior compared to currently used wide bandgap semiconductor materials. For electronic applications, diamond's high electron and hole mobility values enable high speed and high current operation, its low dielectric constant contributes to high frequency operation, its wide bandgap supports a high breakdown electric field and its high thermal conductivity supports high current operation. Diamond-based power and high frequency electronics will operate at power regimes not allowed by current semiconductor electronic devices. The impact is that the exceptional semiconductor properties of diamond will enable a new and more energy efficient class of higher-power, higher-voltage, and higher temperature electronic devices and will transform applications in transportation, manufacturing and energy sectors. To realize the potential of diamond for electronic diodes and transistors it is crucial that the electric field breakdown strength be large and that desired p-type and n-type doping profiles be achieved. The formation of doping profiles with desired variation in both the lateral and vertical directions are key to forming semiconductor junctions and controlling the electric field and breakdown voltages in diode and transistor devices. The goal of this project is to advance the scientific and engineering knowledge needed to form desired doping profiles for diamond electronic devices and to reduce the defects in diamond such that the full high voltage potential of diamond devices is achieved. An additional goal is to train graduate students and summer undergraduate student interns in diamond technology.

The formation of doping profiles in diamond material with desired variation in both the lateral and vertical directions are key to forming semiconductor junctions and controlling the electric field and breakdown voltages in diamond diode and transistor devices. The first objective of this project is develop the processes, know-how and understanding of forming controlled doping profiles in diamond for electronics by using ion implantation coupled with annealing. Diamond annealing will be studied at (1) high pressure and high temperature conditions and (2) metastable conditions of low pressure and high temperature with the surface of the diamond covered with hydrogen to prevent/slow the conversion of diamond to graphite. The second objective of this project is to develop processes, know-how and understanding to reduce point and dislocation defects in the diamond yielding electronic devices with higher breakdown voltages and lower leakage currents. The third objective is to develop the computation tools and diamond material properties understanding to predict doping profiles, to predict annealing process results for dopant activation, and to predict diamond electronic device characteristics.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced the understanding and technology of diamond growth and doping for its application in high voltage, high temperature, and high power electronic devices. Diamond has multiple superb properties as a semiconductor material including high thermal conductivity, ultrawide bandgap, high hole and electron carrier mobility, and high electric field breakdown strength making it potentially the highest performance semiconductor for many applications. However, diamond as a semiconductor material still needs further advances to realize its potential. This project used a combined effort of diamond synthesis, material characterization and computational modeling to improve the diamond by reducing defects and dislocations during diamond growth and by studying the addition of dopants that make diamond semiconducting.

The intellectual merit of this project is that the understanding of the epitaxial growth of diamond has been advanced with studies of the starting substrate preparation including top surface crystallographic orientation and surface preparation, as well as, the plasma-assisted chemical vapor deposition conditions. The morphology of the top growth surface during diamond deposition was studied in detail to reduce dislocations and improve uniformity of dopant addition during growth. Another area of emphasis in this study was the doping of diamond using ion implantation with the result of a better understanding of the diffusion processes of vacancies, the implanted ions (dopants) and displaced carbon atoms. The result of this project has improved diamond growth and processing technology, which advances diamond towards further use in extreme condition electronics and in newer areas including diamond substrates for quantum sensing devices that use diamond-based nitrogen vacancy centers.

The broader impacts included the dissemination of the project research results in journal and conference papers, as well as presentations, to the scientific and engineering community. The project involved three graduate students who received their PhD degrees in engineering or chemistry, as well as training of two postdoctoral research associates. Two new graduate level courses were created including ?Diamond Technology? that covers the properties, growth, processing and applications of diamond and ?Introduction of Quantum Sensor and System Engineering.? Both courses have been offered three times in the past and are being offered again this academic year. These courses have updated the course curriculum at Michigan State University and have been taken by students in several engineering disciplines, Physics and Chemistry. The work on diamond at Michigan State University over the past three decades, including the work on this NSF project, has developed an extensive knowhow and intellectual property set (patents) that was the basis of a new startup company formed in 2019. The start-up company has in the past three years written SBIR/STTR proposals with seven awarded Phase I (three active now) projects, two Phase II projects, and two Phase III projects. It has also raised private  equity financing and within the past three months it has started initial commercial sales. Since the topic of diamond is often of interest to the general public, this project has been used to communicate the importance of basic research funded by the federal government to general audience groups. During the six years of this project multiple presentations have been made at public events including to groups like Kiwanis and Rotary Clubs. The format that we use in these talks is that a material like diamond is an engineering advanced material with properties (like doping) that we adjust (design in) as desired. We then use these advanced materials for products that help improve society in the areas of more efficient use of energy, reduced pollution, improved health care, and improved security.
